title-group.article-title: This Doubly Reflected Communication: Philip Roth's "Autobiographies"

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 1995 Board of Regents of the University of Wisconsin System

p.mixed-citation: Roth clearly links them when he writes in Operation Shylock
he "decided to embark on this nonfictional treatment rather than to plumb the idea in the context, say, of a Zuckerman sequel to The Counterlife" (359) 359
Louis A. Sass
Charles Taylor analyzes the history of philosophical notions of the self in Hegel (1-126) 1
Taylor Sources of the Self
Donald Spence, for example, argues that "the linguistic and narrative aspects of an interpretation may well have priority over its historical truth" (137) 137
Loewald, "Experience" 176 176
Janet Malcolm and other critics who doubt the validity of truth in autobiography to declare fiction the "ideal of unmediated reportage" (138) 138
Oneself 114n114n Oneself

Paul Ricoeur's (Hermeneutics 248)
Ricoeur
248 Hermeneutics
Donald Spence (141) 141
Robert Winer (142) 142
Hans Loewald (146) 146
Norman Holland argues that the reader's expectations differ with regard to fiction and nonfiction: "He has one kind of 'set' for non-fiction, another for fiction" (321). 321
Holland continues, readers "apply criteria of belief" (322) 322

Paul de Man it decidedly is not. In his famed attack on autobiographical dis- course, he stressed that what autobiography aspires to-a knowledge of the self and its world-is founded on an illusion, that rather than provide "a discourse of self- restoration," autobiography knows only the "language of privation" (923)
Metaphors 3434 Metaphors

Paul Eakin, who reasons that although in writing the self, in constructing its fictions, autobiographers come "to understand the self they sought to express as necessarily a product of self-invention," language is a powerful agent whose capacity "to fashion selfhood is not only successful but life-sustaining, necessary to the conduct of human life as we know it" (190-91) 190
Roth alludes repeatedly to Kierkegaard and chooses his Repetition as a source for the epigraphs in Operation Shylock

Michael Sprinker alleges that Kierkegaard, the "most radical expounder of 'truth as subjectivity[,]' is also among the most suspicious questioners of the authority of the subject over his discourse. In this the Kierkegaardian discourse resembles nothing more closely than the Nietzschean text of The Will to Power" (332) 332

Bertel Pedersen maintains, however, that Kierkegaard's "texts then do not, in turn, seek to dominate a textual field openly or by secret erosion, but are directed primarily at those instances and places where textual dominations or ideologies are generated" (115) 115
Meissner's definition of subjectivity (287) 287

Peter Brooks explains, "itself a representation, perhaps an allegory, of interaction or transaction"; and it is the "psycho- analytic intertext" that "obliges the critic to make a transit through a systematic discourse elaborated to describe the dynamics of psychic process" (Psychoanalysis 42, 43) 42
